elements.content: A new series of polyoxometalate (POM) supported transition metal complexes (TMCs), namely, [2-ampH]4[{Zn(H2O)5}Mo7O24]·9H2O (1), [3-ampH]4[{Zn(3-ampy)(H2O)4}Mo7O24]·4H2O (2), [3-ampH]4[{Co(3-ampy)(H2O)4}Mo7O24]·4H2O (3), [2,3-diampH]4[Co(H2O)6][Mo7O24]·6H2O (4), and [2,3-diampH]2[{Zn(2,3-diampH)2(H2O)2}Mo8O27]·2H2O (5) have been synthesized (where amp = aminopyridine and diamp = diaminopyridine) from the corresponding aqueous sodium molybdate solution, by varying the transition metal salts and aminopyridine derivatives in an acidic medium. In compounds 1−4, the POM cluster is [Mo7O24]6−, whereas in compound 5, it is [Mo8O27]6−. In compound 1, the heptamolybdate moiety is functionalized by the zinc-aqua complex [Zn(H2O)5]2+ and the residual negative charges have been compensated by the protonated 2-aminopyridine molecules acting as cations. In the crystal structure of compound 1, a dimer of 2-aminopyridine has been identified as a supramolecular synthon. Compounds 2 and 3 are isomorphous, in which the POM cluster anion supports the zinc and cobalt coordination complexes, {Zn(3-ampy)(H2O)4}2+ and {Co(3-ampy)(H2O)4}2+, respectively. The overall negative charges of the resulting POM supported transition metal complexes in compounds 2 and 3 have been counter-balanced by the protonated 3-aminopyridine molecules. In compound 4, the anionic cluster unit [Mo7O24]6− exists as a discrete moiety, where the species {Co(H2O)4}2+ and protonated 2,3-diaminopyridine act as mere counter cations. Compound 5 is a two-dimensional (2-D) coordination polymer which is constructed by [Mo8O27]6− anion and [Zn(2,3-diampH)2(H2O)4]4+ cation moieties. In the crystal structure of 5, interestingly, a one-dimensional chain is formed by a condensation reaction among [Mo8O27]6− anionic cluster units through the formation of Mo−Ob−Mo (Ob is bridging oxygen) bonds, and these chains, in turn, are laterally interlinked by [Mo8O27]6− supported coordination complexes [{Zn(2,3-diampH)2(H2O)2}Mo8O27]2− (as linker) resulting in the formation of a 2-D porous network having well-defined cavities. All compounds 1−5, that are isolated at an ambient temperature, are characterized by single crystal X-ray crystallography and are additionally characterized by elemental analyses, infrared, thermogravimetric analysis/mass spectral studies. The crystal structures analyses of compounds 2, 3, and 5 show the existence of supramolecular tectons.

elements.content: A series of polyoxometalate supported transition metal complexes 1−5 have been synthesized using a simple aqueous wet synthesis. Their crystal structures have been described in terms of diverse supramolecular interactions.
elements.clean_text: A series of polyoxometalate supported transition metal complexes 1-5 have been synthesized using a simple aqueous wet synthesis. Their crystal structures have been described in terms of diverse supramolecular interactions.

elements.content: Polyoxometalates have become a subject of general interest because of their potential applications in the fields of catalysis, biochemical analysis, medicinal chemistry, and materials science. A recent trend in polyoxometalate (henceforth called as POM) chemistry is the functionalization of the POM cluster anions, to explore more selective applications. In a broad sense, functionalization of a cluster anion can be discussed by three general categories: (i) Multidimensional inorganic−organic hybrid materials that include porous structures (a majority of the materials are synthesized by a hydrothermal technique); a significant contribution, in this area, was made by Zubieta and co-workers and Khan et al. (ii) Replacement of MO6 octahedra of the pertinent cluster anion with transition metal ions (known as substitution) resulting in a transition metal ion substituted lacunary POM cluster anion with higher negative charges (where M = addenda atoms, such as Mo, W, and V, etc.). (iii) Attachment of a transition metal complex (TMC) on the surface of a POM anion using coordinate covalent bonds (known as addition). Category (iii) has received considerable attention in recent times as far as new POM-based materials, having aesthetic supramolecular structures, are concerned. Wang and co-workers have reported crystal structures of reduced and capped Keggin derivatives decorated by transition metal complexes. Notable examples of Keggin heteropolyanion-supported transition metal complexes, that are structurally characterized, include [CuI(phen)2]4[PMoVI 8VIV 6O42{CuI(phen)2]·5H2O, [Ni(phen)3][PMoVI 9MoV 3O40 {Ni(phen)}2], [Cu(4,4′-bipy)]2[SiW12O40{Cu(4,4′-bipy)}4](OH)2·H2O, [Ni(2,2′-bipy)3]1.5[PWVI 10WV 2O40Ni(2,2′-bipy)2(H2O)]·0.5H2O, [Co(1,10′-phen)3]1.5[PMoVI 10MoV 2O40Co(1,10′-phen)2 (H2O)]·0.5H2O, etc. We have shown that the β-[Mo8O28]4− octamolybdate supports two bis(aqua)copper phenanthroline complexes on its surface through its terminal oxygen atoms via coordinate covalent bonds in compound [{Cu(phen)(H2O)2}2(Mo8O26)]·8H2O. A similar octamolybdate supported copper monophenanthroline complex was reported but with copper ions in the 1+ oxidation state. Heptamolybdate isopolyanion, [Mo7O24]6−, can also be functionalized by transition metal complexes; for example, a supramolecular cobalt complex supported on [Mo7O24]6−, [Hapy]4[Co(H2O)5Mo7O24]·9H2O, has been reported by Cao and co-workers. Neumann and co-workers have described a new type of heptamolybdate that supports [MII(DMSO)3]2+ (M = Ru2+ and Os2+) in compounds [NH4]4[RuII(DMSO)3Mo7O24] and [NH4]4[OsII(DMSO)3Mo7O24], respectively. All these above-mentioned POM supported transition meal coordination complexes have been described in terms of their (mainly) structural characterizations. The mechanistic approach of how these cluster anions are formed in a reaction mixture followed by their isolation is not focused. The Ramanan group contributed significantly in this direction. Pavani and Ramanan reported the influence of 2-aminopyridine molecule on the formation of several crystalline molybdates, including linked octamolybdate under hydrothermal conditions. At the same time, Upreti and Ramanan described the structure directing role of hydrogen bonded dimers of phenylenediammonium cations (as synthons) in the isolation of octamolybdate-based inorganic−organic hybrid materials that show diversities in superamolcular assemblies. Ramanan and co-workers, indeed, employed a synthetic strategy to understand the self-assembly of octamolybdate complexes that incorporate a copper/cobalt amine complex and/or the amine under hydrothermal conditions.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Polyoxometalates have become a subject of general interest because of their potential applications in the fields of catalysis, biochemical analysis, medicinal chemistry, and materials science. A recent trend in polyoxometalate (henceforth called as POM) chemistry is the functionalization of the POM cluster anions, to explore more selective applications. In a broad sense, functionalization of a cluster anion can be discussed by three general categories: (i) Multidimensional inorganic-organic hybrid materials that include porous structures (a majority of the materials are synthesized by a hydrothermal technique); a significant contribution, in this area, was made by Zubieta and co-workers and Khan et al. (ii) Replacement of MO6 octahedra of the pertinent cluster anion with transition metal ions (known as substitution) resulting in a transition metal ion substituted lacunary POM cluster anion with higher negative charges (where M = addenda atoms, such as Mo, W, and V, etc.). (iii) Attachment of a transition metal complex (TMC) on the surface of a POM anion using coordinate covalent bonds (known as addition). Category (iii) has received considerable attention in recent times as far as new POM-based materials, having aesthetic supramolecular structures, are concerned. Wang and co-workers have reported crystal structures of reduced and capped Keggin derivatives decorated by transition metal complexes. Notable examples of Keggin heteropolyanion-supported transition metal complexes, that are structurally characterized, include [CuI(phen)2]4[PMoVI 8VIV 6O42{CuI(phen)2]⋅5H2O, [Ni(phen)3][PMoVI 9MoV 3O40 {Ni(phen)}2], [Cu(4,4'-bipy)]2[SiW12O40{Cu(4,4'-bipy)}4](OH)2⋅H2O, [Ni(2,2'-bipy)3]1.5[PWVI 10WV 2O40Ni(2,2'-bipy)2(H2O)]⋅0.5H2O, [Co(1,10'-phen)3]1.5[PMoVI 10MoV 2O40Co(1,10'-phen)2 (H2O)]⋅0.5H2O, etc. We have shown that the β-[Mo8O28]4- octamolybdate supports two bis(aqua)copper phenanthroline complexes on its surface through its terminal oxygen atoms via coordinate covalent bonds in compound [{Cu(phen)(H2O)2}2(Mo8O26)]⋅8H2O. A similar octamolybdate supported copper monophenanthroline complex was reported but with copper ions in the 1+ oxidation state. Heptamolybdate isopolyanion, [Mo7O24]6-, can also be functionalized by transition metal complexes; for example, a supramolecular cobalt complex supported on [Mo7O24]6-, [Hapy]4[Co(H2O)5Mo7O24]⋅9H2O, has been reported by Cao and co-workers. Neumann and co-workers have described a new type of heptamolybdate that supports [MII(DMSO)3]2+ (M = Ru2+ and Os2+) in compounds [NH4]4[RuII(DMSO)3Mo7O24] and [NH4]4[OsII(DMSO)3Mo7O24], respectively. All these above-mentioned POM supported transition meal coordination complexes have been described in terms of their (mainly) structural characterizations. The mechanistic approach of how these cluster anions are formed in a reaction mixture followed by their isolation is not focused. The Ramanan group contributed significantly in this direction. Pavani and Ramanan reported the influence of 2-aminopyridine molecule on the formation of several crystalline molybdates, including linked octamolybdate under hydrothermal conditions. At the same time, Upreti and Ramanan described the structure directing role of hydrogen bonded dimers of phenylenediammonium cations (as synthons) in the isolation of octamolybdate-based inorganic-organic hybrid materials that show diversities in superamolcular assemblies. Ramanan and co-workers, indeed, employed a synthetic strategy to understand the self-assembly of octamolybdate complexes that incorporate a copper/cobalt amine complex and/or the amine under hydrothermal conditions.

elements.content: We have reported here a new series of polyoxometalate supported transition metal complexes [(2-ampH)]4[{Zn(H2O)5}Mo7O24]·9H2O (1), [(3-ampH)]4[{Zn(3-ampy)(H2O)4}Mo7O24]·4H2O (2), [(3-ampH)]4[{Co(3-ampy)(H2O)4}Mo7O24]·4H2O (3), [(2,3-diampH)]4[Co(H2O)6][Mo7O24]·6H2O (4), and [(2,3-diampH)]2[{Zn(2,3-diampH)2(H2O)2}Mo8O27]·2H2O (5) in simple one-pot wet syntheses (not under hydrothermal condition) highlighting their synthesis view (where amp = aminopyridine, and diamp = diaminopyridine). We have described the crystal structures of compounds 1−5, emphasizing diversity in their supramolecular features including synthons and tectons.

We have described the crystal structures of compounds 1-5, emphasizing diversity in their supramolecular features including synthons and tectons.

elements.content: All the chemicals were received as reagent grade and used without any further purification. Elemental analyses were determined by FLASH EA series 1112 CHNS analyzer. Infrared spectra of solid samples obtained as KBr pellets on a JASCO-5300 FTIR spectrophotometer. Thermogravimetric analyses were carried out on a STA 409 PC analyzer and corresponding masses were analyzed by QMS 403 C mass analyzer, under the flow of N2 gas with a heating rate of 5 °C min−1, in the temperature range of 30−1100 °C. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns on the grinded crystals of the compounds 1−5 were recorded on a Bruker diffractometer using Cu Kα1 (1.5406 Å) and Kα2 (1.54439 Å) radiation. The diffuse reflectance UV-visible spectra were measured using UV-3600 Shimadzu UV-Vis spectrometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Measurements

All the chemicals were received as reagent grade and used without any further purification. Elemental analyses were determined by FLASH EA series 1112 CHNS analyzer. Infrared spectra of solid samples obtained as KBr pellets on a JASCO-5300 FTIR spectrophotometer. Thermogravimetric analyses were carried out on a STA 409 PC analyzer and corresponding masses were analyzed by QMS 403 C mass analyzer, under the flow of N2 gas with a heating rate of 5 °C min-1, in the temperature range of 30-1100 °C. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns on the grinded crystals of the compounds 1-5 were recorded on a Bruker diffractometer using Cu Kα1 (1.5406 Å) and Kα2 (1.54439 Å) radiation. The diffuse reflectance UV-visible spectra were measured using UV-3600 Shimadzu UV-Vis spectrometer.

elements.content: Sodium molybdate (1 g, 4.13 mmol in the case of compounds 1−3 and 0.5 g, 2.07 mmol in the case of compounds 4−5) was dissolved in 100 mL of water and its pH was adjusted to 2.0 by conc. HCl. In a separate beaker, the metal salt M(NO3)2·6H2O (M = Zn2+, 0.5 g, 1.68 mmol for compounds 1−2; 0.25 g, 0.86 mmol for compound 5; Co2+, 0.5 g, 1.72 mmol for compound 3 and 0.25 g, 0.86 mmol for compound 4) and aminopyridine derivatives (0.2 g, 2.13 mmol of 2-aminopyridine for compound 1 and 3-aminopyridine for compounds 2−3 and 0.12 g, 1.10 mmol of 2,3-diaminopyridine for compounds 4−5) were dissolved in 20 mL of water. This reaction mixture of aminopyridine derivative and divalent metal salt was added dropwise to the sodium molybdate solution with stirring. The resulting reaction mixture was stirred for 6 h (during stirring, the formation of precipitate/turbidity was dissolved by heating the reaction mixture at 70−80 °C in three to four slots). The reaction mixture was then filtered and kept in an open beaker for crystallization without any disturbance at room temperature. After one week, crystals formed, were filtered, washed with plenty of water, and finally dried at room temperature. One of the single crystals from each, suitable for X-ray diffraction study, was selected and characterized structurally.
elements.clean_text:
A General Synthetic Strategy for Compounds 1-5 

Sodium molybdate (1 g, 4.13 mmol in the case of compounds 1-3 and 0.5 g, 2.07 mmol in the case of compounds 4-5) was dissolved in 100 mL of water and its pH was adjusted to 2.0 by conc. HCl. In a separate beaker, the metal salt M(NO3)2⋅6H2O (M = Zn2+, 0.5 g, 1.68 mmol for compounds 1-2; 0.25 g, 0.86 mmol for compound 5; Co2+, 0.5 g, 1.72 mmol for compound 3 and 0.25 g, 0.86 mmol for compound 4) and aminopyridine derivatives (0.2 g, 2.13 mmol of 2-aminopyridine for compound 1 and 3-aminopyridine for compounds 2-3 and 0.12 g, 1.10 mmol of 2,3-diaminopyridine for compounds 4-5) were dissolved in 20 mL of water. This reaction mixture of aminopyridine derivative and divalent metal salt was added dropwise to the sodium molybdate solution with stirring. The resulting reaction mixture was stirred for 6 h (during stirring, the formation of precipitate/turbidity was dissolved by heating the reaction mixture at 70-80 °C in three to four slots). The reaction mixture was then filtered and kept in an open beaker for crystallization without any disturbance at room temperature. After one week, crystals formed, were filtered, washed with plenty of water, and finally dried at room temperature. One of the single crystals from each, suitable for X-ray diffraction study, was selected and characterized structurally.

Data were measured on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD area detector system [λ(Mo Kα) = 0.71073 Å]; graphite monochromator, 2400 frames were recorded with an ω scan width of 0.3°, each for 5 s, a crystal detector distance of 60 mm, and a collimator of 0.5 mm. The data were reduced using SAINTPLUS, and the structures were solved using SHELXS-97 and refined using SHELXL-97. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. We tried to locate the hydrogen atom of solvent water molecules through differential Fourier maps but could not succeed. A summary of the crystallographic data and structure determination parameters for 1−3 is provided in Table , and for 4−5, it is given in Table . Selected bond lengths and angles for the compound 1 are provided in the Table . Compounds 2 and 3 are isomorphous and bond distances and angles in the crystal structures of compounds 2 and 3 are described in Tables S1 and S4, respectively, in section 2 of . Tables S5 and S6 present the bond lengths and angles for compounds 4 and 5, respectively (see , Section 2).

X-ray Data Collection and Structure Determination

Data were measured on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD area detector system [λ(Mo Kα) = 0.71073 Å]; graphite monochromator, 2400 frames were recorded with an ω scan width of 0.3°, each for 5 s, a crystal detector distance of 60 mm, and a collimator of 0.5 mm. The data were reduced using SAINTPLUS, and the structures were solved using SHELXS-97 and refined using SHELXL-97. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. We tried to locate the hydrogen atom of solvent water molecules through differential Fourier maps but could not succeed. A summary of the crystallographic data and structure determination parameters for 1-3 is provided in Table , and for 4-5, it is given in Table . Selected bond lengths and angles for the compound 1 are provided in the Table . Compounds 2 and 3 are isomorphous and bond distances and angles in the crystal structures of compounds 2 and 3 are described in Tables S1 and S4, respectively, in section 2 of . Tables S5 and S6 present the bond lengths and angles for compounds 4 and 5, respectively (see , Section 2).

Majority of the POM cluster-supported transition metal complexes are synthesized hydrothermally, and in most cases it results in the formation of multidimensional structures. However, we have isolated compounds [(2-ampH)]4[{Zn(H2O)5}Mo7O24]·9H2O (1), [(3-ampH)]4[{Zn(3-ampy)(H2O)4}Mo7O24]·4H2O (2), [(3-ampH)]4[{Co(3-ampy)(H2O)4}Mo7O24]·4H2O (3), [(2,3-diampH)]4[Co(H2O)6][Mo7O24]·6H2O (4), and [(2,3-diampH)]2[{Zn(2,3-diampH)2(H2O)2}Mo8O27]·2H2O (5) in a conventional wet synthesis at room temperature, and we found that compounds 1−4 are discrete and 5 is a coordination polymer. The crystal structure of cobalt analogue of compound 1 is reported earlier, for which synthesis was performed by a hydrothermal technique, and in the relevant article it was mentioned that this hydrothermal procedure remained unsuccessful to produce zinc analogue. The present synthesis offers the successful preparation of both zinc (1) and cobalt (1a) analogues. The compounds 1 and 1a are crystallized in orthorhombic space group, Pna2(1) (crystal data for 1a: a = 14.9527(6), b = 17.2509(6), c = 19.4734(7) Å, α = β = γ = 90°), which is identical to that of the published cobalt compound. The crystal structure of compound 1a will not be discussed further in this article. All the compounds 1−5 were isolated in an acidic aqueous medium (pH 3−6). For compounds 1−4, the POM cluster anion is heptamolybdate anion, [Mo7O24]6−. In the case of compound [(2,3-diampH2)]2[{Zn(2,3-diampH)2(H2O)4}Mo8O27]·2H2O (5), the POM cluster anion is an unusual octamolybdate anion, [Mo8O27]6−. The generation of heptamolydate [Mo7O24]6− cluster anion and octamolybdate [Mo8O27]6− from an aqueous molybdate solution in the presence of an aromatic diamine is well-documented. Pavani and Ramanan described the synthesis and characterization of hepta- and octa-molybdates and proposed a rational model to explain the influence of 2-aminopyridine on their formation under hydrothermal conditions. Even though the present syntheses are not performed under hydrothermal conditions, the chemistry of formation of molybdates (mainly hepta- and octa-molybdates) in our simple nonhydrothermal wet synthesis should be comparable to that under hydrothermal conditions, because in both cases, the syntheses are performed in an acidified aqueous medium. When sodium molybdate is dissolved in an aqueous solution in the presence of 2-aminopyridine, 3-aminopyridine, or 2,3-diaminopyridine, the aminopyridine molecule forms weak complexes with transition metals and is readily labile in the presence of hydroxyl ligand during hydrolysis and condensation reactions take place to produce an −Mo−O−Mo−O−Mo− network leading to hepta- or octa-molybdate cluster anion. On the basis of the solids obtained in the present study, it is reasonable to assume that the heptamolybate cluster anion dominates the equilibrium. Although the predominant cluster is the heptamolybdate anion, the other molybdenum species such as [MoO3(OH)]−, MoO2(OH)2(H2O)2, [Mo8O26]4−, and [H2Mo8O28]6− may form at equilibrium due to a slight change in the pH and ionic strength of the medium. Crystallization of a solid from such reaction mixture (an equilibrium consisting of a range of POM clusters and an aminopyridine) would be governed by the electrostatic interactions between the POM cluster anion and the organic amine cation. Since heptamolybdates are not very known to be protonated, the relevant packing of the concerned solids is influenced by the hydrogen bonding interactions among organic aminopyridinium cation, POM cluster anion, and lattice water molecules. The relatively larger POM cluster anion [Mo8O27]6− with its large negative charge (formed from other smaller POM fragments) is not completely stable in the aqueous solution, and thereby it tends to condense to form one-dimensional (1-D) polymeric chains that are further laterally linked by POM coordinated zinc complex of the composition [{Zn(2,3-diampH)2(H2O)4}Mo8O27]2− in compound 5.

Results and Discussion

Syntheses

Majority of the POM cluster-supported transition metal complexes are synthesized hydrothermally, and in most cases it results in the formation of multidimensional structures. However, we have isolated compounds [(2-ampH)]4[{Zn(H2O)5}Mo7O24]⋅9H2O (1), [(3-ampH)]4[{Zn(3-ampy)(H2O)4}Mo7O24]⋅4H2O (2), [(3-ampH)]4[{Co(3-ampy)(H2O)4}Mo7O24]⋅4H2O (3), [(2,3-diampH)]4[Co(H2O)6][Mo7O24]⋅6H2O (4), and [(2,3-diampH)]2[{Zn(2,3-diampH)2(H2O)2}Mo8O27]⋅2H2O (5) in a conventional wet synthesis at room temperature, and we found that compounds 1-4 are discrete and 5 is a coordination polymer. The crystal structure of cobalt analogue of compound 1 is reported earlier, for which synthesis was performed by a hydrothermal technique, and in the relevant article it was mentioned that this hydrothermal procedure remained unsuccessful to produce zinc analogue. The present synthesis offers the successful preparation of both zinc (1) and cobalt (1a) analogues. The compounds 1 and 1a are crystallized in orthorhombic space group, Pna2(1) (crystal data for 1a: a = 14.9527(6), b = 17.2509(6), c = 19.4734(7) Å, α = β = γ = 90°), which is identical to that of the published cobalt compound. The crystal structure of compound 1a will not be discussed further in this article. All the compounds 1-5 were isolated in an acidic aqueous medium (pH 3-6). For compounds 1-4, the POM cluster anion is heptamolybdate anion, [Mo7O24]6-. In the case of compound [(2,3-diampH2)]2[{Zn(2,3-diampH)2(H2O)4}Mo8O27]⋅2H2O (5), the POM cluster anion is an unusual octamolybdate anion, [Mo8O27]6-. The generation of heptamolydate [Mo7O24]6- cluster anion and octamolybdate [Mo8O27]6- from an aqueous molybdate solution in the presence of an aromatic diamine is well-documented. Pavani and Ramanan described the synthesis and characterization of hepta- and octa-molybdates and proposed a rational model to explain the influence of 2-aminopyridine on their formation under hydrothermal conditions. Even though the present syntheses are not performed under hydrothermal conditions, the chemistry of formation of molybdates (mainly hepta- and octa-molybdates) in our simple nonhydrothermal wet synthesis should be comparable to that under hydrothermal conditions, because in both cases, the syntheses are performed in an acidified aqueous medium. When sodium molybdate is dissolved in an aqueous solution in the presence of 2-aminopyridine, 3-aminopyridine, or 2,3-diaminopyridine, the aminopyridine molecule forms weak complexes with transition metals and is readily labile in the presence of hydroxyl ligand during hydrolysis and condensation reactions take place to produce an -Mo-O-Mo-O-Mo- network leading to hepta- or octa-molybdate cluster anion. On the basis of the solids obtained in the present study, it is reasonable to assume that the heptamolybate cluster anion dominates the equilibrium. Although the predominant cluster is the heptamolybdate anion, the other molybdenum species such as [MoO3(OH)]-, MoO2(OH)2(H2O)2, [Mo8O26]4-, and [H2Mo8O28]6- may form at equilibrium due to a slight change in the pH and ionic strength of the medium. Crystallization of a solid from such reaction mixture (an equilibrium consisting of a range of POM clusters and an aminopyridine) would be governed by the electrostatic interactions between the POM cluster anion and the organic amine cation. Since heptamolybdates are not very known to be protonated, the relevant packing of the concerned solids is influenced by the hydrogen bonding interactions among organic aminopyridinium cation, POM cluster anion, and lattice water molecules. The relatively larger POM cluster anion [Mo8O27]6- with its large negative charge (formed from other smaller POM fragments) is not completely stable in the aqueous solution, and thereby it tends to condense to form one-dimensional (1-D) polymeric chains that are further laterally linked by POM coordinated zinc complex of the composition [{Zn(2,3-diampH)2(H2O)4}Mo8O27]2- in compound 5.

elements.content: It is interesting to observe (vide infra) that among 2-aminopyridine (2-amp) and 3-aminopyridine (3-amp) molecules, used in the syntheses of compounds 1 (2-amp) , 2 (3-amp), and 3 (3-amp), only 3-aminopyridine is found to coordinate to the metal center (compounds 2 and 3). As far as electron donation tendency of ring nitrogen is concerned, 2-aminopyridine is a good donor compared to 3-aminopyridine. We have attempted to explain this inconsistency by taking into consideration that 2-aminopyridine, on coordination to a metal ion through its ring nitrogen, would experience steric interactions, that would not have occurred in the case of 3-aminopyridine on its coordination via its ring nitrogen atom. This discrepancy can also be explained by the fact that 2-aminopyridine may undergo tautomerization with protonation of ring nitrogen as shown in Scheme , which is not achievable by 3-aminopyridine.
elements.clean_text: It is interesting to observe (vide infra) that among 2-aminopyridine (2-amp) and 3-aminopyridine (3-amp) molecules, used in the syntheses of compounds 1 (2-amp) , 2 (3-amp), and 3 (3-amp), only 3-aminopyridine is found to coordinate to the metal center (compounds 2 and 3). As far as electron donation tendency of ring nitrogen is concerned, 2-aminopyridine is a good donor compared to 3-aminopyridine. We have attempted to explain this inconsistency by taking into consideration that 2-aminopyridine, on coordination to a metal ion through its ring nitrogen, would experience steric interactions, that would not have occurred in the case of 3-aminopyridine on its coordination via its ring nitrogen atom. This discrepancy can also be explained by the fact that 2-aminopyridine may undergo tautomerization with protonation of ring nitrogen as shown in Scheme , which is not achievable by 3-aminopyridine.

In the case of compounds [2,3-diampH)4[Co(H2O)6][Mo7O24]·6H2O (4) and [2,3-diampH]2[{Zn(2,3-diampH)2(H2O)2}Mo8O27]·2H2O (5), 2,3-diaminopyridine has been used as a ligand, and it has been found that in compound 5, this is coordinated to the Zn2+ ion and it remains uncoordinated in compound 4. The ring nitrogen is not expected to coordinate based on the logic described above. The basis of why the Zn2+ ion is preferred to coordinate to an amine nitrogen atom of 2,3-diaminopyridine in compound 5 over Co2+ in compound 4 can be explained by the fact that the Zn2+ ion is a better electron acceptor than the Co2+ ion (the position of zinc is more on the right side compared to cobalt in the same period).

elements.content: Compound [(2-ampH)]4[{Zn(H2O)5}Mo7O24]·9H2O (1) is crystallized in orthorhombic space group, Pnma. The relevant asymmetric unit contains [Mo5O16]3− (three Mo atoms and eight oxygen atoms are in half occupancies), one zinc-aqua complex [Zn(H2O)4]2+, that is covalently linked to isopolyanion (zinc atom and three oxygen atoms of three water molecules are in half occupancies), two protonated 2-aminopyridine molecules and five lattice water molecules (one of these water molecules in half occupancy). The asymmetric unit is shown in Figure a excluding organic amine cations. On the basis of this asymmetric unit, molecular formula of 1 can be formulated as [(2-ampH)]4[{Zn(H2O)5}Mo7O24]·9H2O (1). The molecular structure is shown in Figure b. In the crystal structure, the divalent zinc-aqua complex [Zn(H2O)5]2+ is supported by the heptamolybdate [Mo7O24]6− cluster anion via Mo−Ot−Zn coordinate covalent bond (where Ot is a terminal oxygen on molybdenum), resulting in the formation of POM supported zinc-aqua complex [Mo7O24{Zn(H2O)5}]4−, the negative charges of which have been compensated by four mono protonated 2-aminopyridine molecules. The oxygen bonding modes in the POM supported zinc-aqua complex [Mo7O24{Zn(H2O)5}]4−can be classified into four different (Ot, μ2, μ3, and μ4) categories. Those are in the ranges of Mo−Ot = 1.705(9)−1.743(13) Å, Mo−O(μ2) = 1.754(12)−2.543(11) Å, Mo−O(μ3) = 1.881(8)−2.252(8) Å, and Mo−O(μ4) = 2.149(12)−2.231(8) Å. The zinc cation is linked to the cluster anion via Zn(1)−O(1)−Mo(1), and the remaining five coordination sites of zinc atom is satisfied by aqua ligands, and hence the metal ion possesses distorted octahedral geometry. The bond lengths of Zn−O vary in the range of 1.998(16)−2.105(12) Å. The bond angle of Zn(1)−O(1)−Mo(1) is 177.1(7)o, which clearly indicates the transition metal complex {Zn(H2O)5}2+ linked the [Mo7O24]6− cluster anion via Mo−Ot bond in a nearly linear fashion. The C(6) atom of one of the 2-aminopyridine rings is largely disordered; N(4A) and N(4B) of the same 2-aminopyridine molecule are characterized with half occupancies. The list of selected bond lengths and bond angles in compound 1 is given in the Table .

elements.content: The crystal structrure analysis of compound 1 revealed the occurrence of a supramolecular dimer of 2-aminopyridine as a synthon (Scheme ). The term “supramolecular synthon” was coined by Desiraju to describe building blocks that are common to many structures and hence can be used to order specific groups in the solid state. Upreti and Ramanan have demonstrated that hydrogen bonded dimers of phenylenediamine act as supramolecular synthons that are responsible for the ordered assembly of hybrid salts based on octamolybdate anions. This prompted us to investigate the occurrence of such supramolecular synthon in the crystal structures of the present study because we are also dealing with similar POM cluster anions and aromatic amines. In the crystal structure of compound 1, the hydrogens of the amines of 2-aminopyridine could not be located. There are two crystallographically independent 2-aminopyridine molecules in the relevant asymmetric unit and one of these, which undergoes dimerization through hydrogen bond (Scheme ), contains disordered amine nitrogen (over two positions).
elements.clean_text:
Identification of a Supramolecular Synthon (Dimer of 2-Aminopyridine) in the Construction of an Assembly of a Water Chain and POM Cluster Anion

The crystal structrure analysis of compound 1 revealed the occurrence of a supramolecular dimer of 2-aminopyridine as a synthon (Scheme ). The term "supramolecular synthon" was coined by Desiraju to describe building blocks that are common to many structures and hence can be used to order specific groups in the solid state. Upreti and Ramanan have demonstrated that hydrogen bonded dimers of phenylenediamine act as supramolecular synthons that are responsible for the ordered assembly of hybrid salts based on octamolybdate anions. This prompted us to investigate the occurrence of such supramolecular synthon in the crystal structures of the present study because we are also dealing with similar POM cluster anions and aromatic amines. In the crystal structure of compound 1, the hydrogens of the amines of 2-aminopyridine could not be located. There are two crystallographically independent 2-aminopyridine molecules in the relevant asymmetric unit and one of these, which undergoes dimerization through hydrogen bond (Scheme ), contains disordered amine nitrogen (over two positions).

elements.content: This dimer of 2-aminopyridine (supramolecular synthon) interacts with POM cluster anion as well as with a supramolecular water chain using C−H···O hydrogen bonds as shown in Figure (the water chain is shown in green and the POM cluster anions in polyhedral representation). The water chain is constructed as follows: four lattice water molecules (namely, O21, O23, O24, O25) and their corresponding symmetry equivalents form a water heptamer (H2O)7 cluster (water heptamer is taken instead of water octamer because each O24 water oxygen is characterized with half occupancy), which self-assembles into a supramolecular water chain running along the crystallographic b axis (Figure a). The formation of this water chain is favored by its supramolelcular hydrogen bonding interactions with its surrounding POM supported complex cation and the supramolecular synthon as shown in Figures b and , respectively. Thus, extensive hydrogen bonding interactions (O−H···O, N−H···O, and C−H···O) have been observed in the crystal structure of 1 that involve terminal and bridging oxygen atoms of heptamolybdate anion, zinc coordinated water molecules, and protonated 2-aminopyridine moieties. This results in an intricate three-dimensional (3-D) supramolecular network having well-defined voids that accommodate the supramolecular synthons as guests (Figure ), as if the synthons act as the template for such 3-D construction. The ring nitrogen of 2-aminopyridine is more basic than the amine group nitrogen, and hence the protonation is likely to be taken place at its ring nitrogen. We tried to locate the hydrogen atoms on the protonation site, amine nitrogens, and hydrogen atoms of water molecules through a differential Fourier map without success. Thus the hydrogen bonding distances are given as O···O and N···O distances (Table ). The C−H···O hydrogen bonding parameters are listed in Table .

Compound 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic system (space group Cc). The asymmetric unit in the crystal structure of 2 is composed of a discrete heptamolybdate anion supported zinc coordination complex [{Zn(3-ampy)(H2O)4}Mo7O24]4−, four mono protonated 3-aminopyridine molecules, and four lattice water molecules giving rise to the full molecule [3-ampH]4[{Zn(3-ampy)(H2O)4}Mo7O24]·4H2O (2). The relevant thermal ellipsoidal plot is shown in Figure . The crystal structure of compound 2 differs from compound 1 in the zinc cation’s coordination environment: in the crystal structure of compound 1, Zn2+ ion coordinate-covalently linked with POM anion but not with 2-amp molecule, whereas in the case of compound 2, the Zn2+ ion is coordinate-covalently coordinated with both POM anion and 3-amp molecule (Figure ). The co-ordination site of each Zn2+ ion in the crystal structure of compound 2 is a distorted octahedron formed by one terminal oxygen atom from heptamolybdate anion, one 3-aminopyridine molecule, and the other four positions of the octahedron are coordinated by four aqua ligands. We believe that the less steric hindrance in 3-aminopyridine molecule, compared to 2-aminopyridine molecule in compound 1, is the possible driving force for its coordination to zinc cation. The molybdenum−oxygen distances in 2 can be grouped into four sets: Molybdenum-terminal oxygen (Mo−Ot), 1.708(2)−1.731(2) Å; Mo−O(μ2) = 1.736(2)−2.556(3) Å, Mo−O(μ3) = 1.863(2)−2.308(2) Å, and Mo−O(μ4) = 2.108(2)−2.266(2) Å. The list of selected bond lengths and bond angles in the crystal structure of compound 2 is given in Table S1, section 2 in .

elements.content: In the crystal structure of compound [3-ampH]4[{Zn(3-ampy)(H2O)4}Mo7O24]·4H2O (2), an acyclic water pentamer is found to be formed from three lattice water molecules O(30), O(31), O(32) and two zinc-coordinated water molecules O(27) and O(28) (as shown Figure S1, , Section 2). The O−H···O hydrogen bonding distances for the water pentamer and between the pentamer and its surrounding are presented in Table S2, section 3 in . In this context, it is worth mentioning that a cyclic water pentamer (formed from three lattice water molecules and two copper coordinated water molecules) has been observed in the crystal structure of compound {Cu(pz)2(H2O)4}[{Cu(pz)2(H2O)}2{Cu(pz)4}2{HP2Mo5O23}2]·6H2O, as described by Thomas and Ramanan. In the present study, the water pentamer along with zinc ion acts as the supramolecular glue to link the POM cluster anions resulting in the formation of a 1-D chain as shown in Figure S3 (, Section 2). These chains are again laterally linked by supramolecular O−H···O hydrogen bonding interactions (shown in purple dot lines, Figure S4, , Section 2) that involve O22 (a terminal oxygen atom of the POM cluster anion) and O30 (part of water pentamer). Another mode of O−H···O hydrogen bonding interactions (shown in blue dot lines, Figure S4, , Section 2), which are also responsible for the formation of the same layer, involves a pair of hydrogen bonding interactions: (i) O2 (a terminal oxygen atom of the POM cluster anion) and O29 (a lattice water molecule) which is further hydrogen bonded to zinc-coordinates water O26 and O7, a terminal oxygen atom of the POM cluster anion. These layers stack one after another and are linked again by O−H···O hydrogen bonding interactions resulting in a 3-D supramolecular network having well-defined irregular rectangular grid channels with an approximate inner dimension of 28.90 × 2.90 Å2 (Figure a) occupied by the 3-aminopyridium cations as guests (Figure b). The formation of a 3-D supramolecular structure arises from the stacking of the one-to-one layers. In the network, there are four different crystallographically independent 3-aminopyridium cations, namely, “N3N4”, “N5N6”, “N7N8”, and “N9N10”. The “N9N10” type cations are located in the channels (vide supra). Besides the above-described O−H···O hydrogen bonding interactions, there are significant N−H···O/O−H···N and C−H···O hydrogen bonding interactions between all four types of 3-aminopyridinium cations, namely, “N3N4”, “N5N6”, “N7N8”, and “N9N10” and isoplyanion [Mo7O24]6− resulting in an intricate supramolecular network in the crystal structure of compound 2. The immediate C−H···O and N−H···O/O−H···N hydrogen bonding interactions around “N3N4”, “N5N6”, “N7N8”, and “N9N10” type cations and zinc coordinated 3-aminopyridine molecule (“N1N2” type) are shown in , Section 2, Figures S5a, S5b, S5c, S5d and S5e, respectively. The detailed hydrogen bonding parameters are presented in Table S3, section S3 in . Since the hydrogen of amine groups are not located in the crystal structure, the N−H···O/O−H···N distances are presented as N···O distances. In the crystal structure of compound 2, the view of the molecular packing of the zinc-coordinated aminopyridine molecules (“N1N2” type) and aminopyridinium cations (“N3N4”, “N5N6”, “N7N8”, and “N9N10” type) is shown in Figure S6, , Section 2 which shows that the cationic pyridines (“N3N4”, “N5N6”, “N7N8”, and “N9N10” type) are perpendicular to the zinc coordinated neutral “N1N2” type pyridine.

The O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonding distances for the water pentamer and between the pentamer and its surrounding are presented in Table S2, section 3 in . In the present study, the water pentamer along with zinc ion acts as the supramolecular glue to link the POM cluster anions resulting in the formation of a 1-D chain as shown in Figure S3 (, Section 2). These chains are again laterally linked by supramolecular O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonding interactions (shown in purple dot lines, Figure S4, , Section 2) that involve O22 (a terminal oxygen atom of the POM cluster anion) and O30 (part of water pentamer). Another mode of O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonding interactions (shown in blue dot lines, Figure S4, , Section 2), which are also responsible for the formation of the same layer, involves a pair of hydrogen bonding interactions: (i) O2 (a terminal oxygen atom of the POM cluster anion) and O29 (a lattice water molecule) which is further hydrogen bonded to zinc-coordinates water O26 and O7, a terminal oxygen atom of the POM cluster anion. These layers stack one after another and are linked again by O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonding interactions resulting in a 3-D supramolecular network having well-defined irregular rectangular grid channels with an approximate inner dimension of 28.90 × 2.90 Å2 (Figure a) occupied by the 3-aminopyridium cations as guests (Figure b). The formation of a 3-D supramolecular structure arises from the stacking of the one-to-one layers. In the network, there are four different crystallographically independent 3-aminopyridium cations, namely, "N3N4", "N5N6", "N7N8", and "N9N10". The "N9N10" type cations are located in the channels (vide supra). Besides the above-described O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonding interactions, there are significant N-H⋅⋅⋅O/O-H⋅⋅⋅N and C-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonding interactions between all four types of 3-aminopyridinium cations, namely, "N3N4", "N5N6", "N7N8", and "N9N10" and isoplyanion [Mo7O24]6- resulting in an intricate supramolecular network in the crystal structure of compound 2. The immediate C-H⋅⋅⋅O and N-H⋅⋅⋅O/O-H⋅⋅⋅N hydrogen bonding interactions around "N3N4", "N5N6", "N7N8", and "N9N10" type cations and zinc coordinated 3-aminopyridine molecule ("N1N2" type) are shown in , Section 2, Figures S5a, S5b, S5c, S5d and S5e, respectively. The detailed hydrogen bonding parameters are presented in Table S3, section S3 in . Since the hydrogen of amine groups are not located in the crystal structure, the N-H⋅⋅⋅O/O-H⋅⋅⋅N distances are presented as N⋅⋅⋅O distances. In the crystal structure of compound 2, the view of the molecular packing of the zinc-coordinated aminopyridine molecules ("N1N2" type) and aminopyridinium cations ("N3N4", "N5N6", "N7N8", and "N9N10" type) is shown in Figure S6, , Section 2 which shows that the cationic pyridines ("N3N4", "N5N6", "N7N8", and "N9N10" type) are perpendicular to the zinc coordinated neutral "N1N2" type pyridine.

elements.content: As shown in Table , both compounds 2 and 3 are isomorphous, and accordingly the unit cell volume, cell data, space group, number of lattice water molecules etc. of 2 and 3 are identical. They differ in their metal contents, that is, compound [3-ampH]4[{Co(3-ampy)(H2O)4}Mo7O24]·4H2O (3) is cobalt analogue of zinc-containing compound [3-ampH]4[{Zn(3-ampy)(H2O)4}Mo7O24]·4H2O (2). Since the molecular structure of compound 2, including its supramolecular structure, has been described in the preceding section in detail, the structural details of compound 3 is not described again here. The Table S4 of bond distances and angles for compound 3 is provided with , Section 3.

Structural Description of Compound [3-ampH]4[{Co(3-ampy)(H2O)4}Mo7O24]⋅4H2O (3)

As shown in Table , both compounds 2 and 3 are isomorphous, and accordingly the unit cell volume, cell data, space group, number of lattice water molecules etc. of 2 and 3 are identical. They differ in their metal contents, that is, compound [3-ampH]4[{Co(3-ampy)(H2O)4}Mo7O24]⋅4H2O (3) is cobalt analogue of zinc-containing compound [3-ampH]4[{Zn(3-ampy)(H2O)4}Mo7O24]⋅4H2O (2). Since the molecular structure of compound 2, including its supramolecular structure, has been described in the preceding section in detail, the structural details of compound 3 is not described again here. The Table S4 of bond distances and angles for compound 3 is provided with , Section 3.

elements.content: The pink colored crystals of compound 4 can be easily be grown from an aqueous solution by slow evaporation. Compound 4 crystallizes in monoclinic space group C2/c. The asymmetric unit contains half of the POM cluster anion [Mo7O24]6−, two mono protonated 2,3-diaminopyridine molecules, half of the complex cation [Co(H2O)6]2+ with half occupancy of cobalt, and three solvent water molecules. The molecular structure of compound 4 is presented in Figure . In the molecular structure, cobalt-aqua complex [Co(H2O)6]2+ exists as a discrete entity and partially fulfills the negative charges of the POM cluster anion. The residual negative charges have been compensated by four protonated 2,3-diaminopyridine molecules (Figure ). The Mo−O bond lengths are within the range of Mo−O bond distances of other [Mo7O24]6− clusters found in compounds 1−3 (vide supra). The Co−O bond lengths vary in the range of 1.904−2.229 Å. The crystal data and structural parameters are given in Table . The selected bond lengths and bond angles were given in Table S5, Section 3 in .

The pink colored crystals of compound 4 can be easily be grown from an aqueous solution by slow evaporation. Compound 4 crystallizes in monoclinic space group C2/c. The asymmetric unit contains half of the POM cluster anion [Mo7O24]6-, two mono protonated 2,3-diaminopyridine molecules, half of the complex cation [Co(H2O)6]2+ with half occupancy of cobalt, and three solvent water molecules. The molecular structure of compound 4 is presented in Figure . In the molecular structure, cobalt-aqua complex [Co(H2O)6]2+ exists as a discrete entity and partially fulfills the negative charges of the POM cluster anion. The residual negative charges have been compensated by four protonated 2,3-diaminopyridine molecules (Figure ). The Mo-O bond lengths are within the range of Mo-O bond distances of other [Mo7O24]6- clusters found in compounds 1-3 (vide supra). The Co-O bond lengths vary in the range of 1.904-2.229 Å. The crystal data and structural parameters are given in Table . The selected bond lengths and bond angles were given in Table S5, Section 3 in .

elements.content: The yellow-colored crystals of compound 5 were isolated from an aqueous solution. Compound 5 crystallizes in monoclinic space group C2/c. The relevant crystal data and refinement parameters for compound 5 are given in Table . The asymmetric unit of the crystal of compound 5 (Figure a) can be represented as [2,3-diampH] [MoVI 4O13.5ZnII 0.5(H2O)(2,3-diampH)]·H2O, and thus the molecular formula of compound 5 is described as [2,3-diampH]2[{Zn(2,3-diampH)2(H2O)2}Mo8O27]·2H2O. The corresponding molecular structure is shown in Figure b. In the crystal structure, the zinc ion and one oxygen atom (O12, Figure a) are characterized in their special positions. As shown in Figure b, the coordination complex [Zn(H2O)2(2,3-diampH)2]2+ is coordinated by the POM cluster anion [Mo8O27]6− via the terminal oxygen atom (O1, Figure ) giving rise to the POM supported zinc-coordination complex [{Zn(2,3-diampH)2(H2O)2}Mo8O27]2−, two negative charges of which are compensated by two protonated 2,3-diaminopyridine molecules resulting in the isolation of compound 5. Notably, the zinc-coordinated 2,3-diaminopyridine molecules are monoprotonated.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure Description of Compound [2,3-diampH]2[{Zn(2,3-diampH)2(H2O)2}Mo8O27]⋅2H2O (5)

The yellow-colored crystals of compound 5 were isolated from an aqueous solution. Compound 5 crystallizes in monoclinic space group C2/c. The relevant crystal data and refinement parameters for compound 5 are given in Table . The asymmetric unit of the crystal of compound 5 (Figure a) can be represented as [2,3-diampH] [MoVI 4O13.5ZnII 0.5(H2O)(2,3-diampH)]⋅H2O, and thus the molecular formula of compound 5 is described as [2,3-diampH]2[{Zn(2,3-diampH)2(H2O)2}Mo8O27]⋅2H2O. The corresponding molecular structure is shown in Figure b. In the crystal structure, the zinc ion and one oxygen atom (O12, Figure a) are characterized in their special positions. As shown in Figure b, the coordination complex [Zn(H2O)2(2,3-diampH)2]2+ is coordinated by the POM cluster anion [Mo8O27]6- via the terminal oxygen atom (O1, Figure ) giving rise to the POM supported zinc-coordination complex [{Zn(2,3-diampH)2(H2O)2}Mo8O27]2-, two negative charges of which are compensated by two protonated 2,3-diaminopyridine molecules resulting in the isolation of compound 5. Notably, the zinc-coordinated 2,3-diaminopyridine molecules are monoprotonated.

elements.content: The rare type octamolydate cluster anion [Mo8O27]6−, found in compound 5, is different from the most common octamolybdate anion [Mo8O26]4− by having one extra MoO bond (more specifically, there are two MoO bonds with half occupancies, that are involved in corner sharing) in compound 5. The Mo−O groups in the crystal structure of 5 can be grouped into four categories: There are 16 Mo−Ot with bond lengths in the range of 1.689(5)−1.898(2) Å; six μ2 type bridged Mo−Ob bonds with distances varying in between 1.753(5)−2.309(5) Å; four μ3 type bridging molybdenum−oxygen distances in the range of 1.857(5)−2.328(5) Å; and two bridging μ4 type molybdenum−oxygen distances in the range of 1.948(5)−2.415(5) Å. The selected bond lengths and bond angles for compound 5 are given in Table S6, Section 3 in . The same cluster [Mo8O27]6− is known to exist in compound [{H2DABCO}2{H2pipz}][Mo8O27] in which the cluster anion does not support any organic cation H2DABCO}2/H2pipz by coordinate covalent bonds and is also found to exist through single common corner sharing in compounds (NH4)6Mo8O27·4H2O and (C4H12N2)3Mo8O27. In all these compounds, the cluster anions condense via Mo−O−Mo bonds to a 1-D chain. In the present compound [2,3-diampH]2[{Zn(2,3-diampH)2(H2O)2}Mo8O27]·2H2O (5), a similar chain is formed by a Mo4−O12−Mo4 bonds along the chain axis (crystallographic c axis), in which the each cluster is functionalized by zinc coordination complexes [{Zn(2,3-diampH)2(H2O)2}]4+ as shown in Figure . This type of POM-based chain, formed exclusively by Mo−Ob−Mo bonds, is very rare in the literature. This chain undergoes lateral linking by coordination of adjacent POM cluster anions through Mo1O1−Zn1 coordinate covalent bonds resulting in the formation of a two-dimensional (2-D) network having well-defined honeycomb cavities (Figure a) in which noncoordinated 2,3-diaminopyridine molecules and solvent water molecules are present (Figure b). The relevant packing diagram shows that the coordinated organic ligands (2,3-diaminopyridine molecules) are stacked over each other through π···π interaction (Figure S8, ). The weak supramolecular hydrogen bonding interactions such as N−H···O/O−H···N and C−H···O interactions among these 2-D layers (Figure ) result in an intricate 3-D network. The immediate environment of coordinated and noncoordinated 2,3-diaminopyridine molecules through N−H···O/O−H···N and C−H···O interactions is shown in S7 in the section of . The corresponding hydrogen bonding distances are given in the Table S7 (see , Section 3).

(b) A view of the accommodation of noncoordinated 2,3-diaminopyridine molecules as guests in the honeycomb cavities. elements.content: Molecules with sticky surfaces with interactions that are dominated by specific attractive forces that induce the assembly of aggregates with controlled geometries are called tectons. Tectons interact with their neighbors in well-defined ways, as they inherently possess the molecular structure and intermolecular recognition features to predictably self-assemble into precise networks. We mentioned in the previous section that compounds 2 and 3 are isomorphous, and accordingly we have described crystal structure analysis of only one of these compounds in detail (compound 2, vide supra). In the relevant crystal structure, the POM cluster anion having an oxygen-rich surface undergoes supramolecular hydrogen bonding interactions with neighboring POM clusters through lattice and metal-coordinated water molecules. Thus, in the crystal structures of compounds 2 and 3, the entity [{M(3-ampy)(H2O)4}Mo7O24]4− (M = Zn2+ and Co2+) can be described as a tecton because the cluster anion has a sticky surface, capable of interacting with nearby neighbors by a specific attractive force (O−H···O hydrogen bonding interactions), and induces an well-defined assembly of cluster anions, water molecules, and metal coordination complexes.
elements.clean_text:
POM Cluster Ion Functionalized by a Zn/Co Coordination Complex as a Tecton

Molecules with sticky surfaces with interactions that are dominated by specific attractive forces that induce the assembly of aggregates with controlled geometries are called tectons. Tectons interact with their neighbors in well-defined ways, as they inherently possess the molecular structure and intermolecular recognition features to predictably self-assemble into precise networks. We mentioned in the previous section that compounds 2 and 3 are isomorphous, and accordingly we have described crystal structure analysis of only one of these compounds in detail (compound 2, vide supra). In the relevant crystal structure, the POM cluster anion having an oxygen-rich surface undergoes supramolecular hydrogen bonding interactions with neighboring POM clusters through lattice and metal-coordinated water molecules. Thus, in the crystal structures of compounds 2 and 3, the entity [{M(3-ampy)(H2O)4}Mo7O24]4- (M = Zn2+ and Co2+) can be described as a tecton because the cluster anion has a sticky surface, capable of interacting with nearby neighbors by a specific attractive force (O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonding interactions), and induces an well-defined assembly of cluster anions, water molecules, and metal coordination complexes.

elements.content: In the case of compound [2,3-diampH]2[{Zn(2,3-diampH)2(H2O)2}Mo8O27]·2H2O (5), the POM supported zinc coordination complex [{Zn(2,3-diampH)2(H2O)2}Mo8O27]2− can be considered a tecton in the sense that the cluster anion, functionalized by zinc coordination complex, induces a self-assembly by well-defined forces of covalent and coordinate covalent bonds (vide supra). In this case, the tecton possesses inherent molecular structure and shows the intermolecular recognition characteristics that can predict the self-assembly of an expected 2-D network.

Similar diffraction patterns for the simulated data (calculated from the single crystal X-ray data) and observed data prove the bulk homogeneity of the samples (see Section 5 of for the PXRD patterns of the compounds 1−5).
elements.clean_text:
Powder X-ray Diffraction Study

X-ray powder diffraction data for the grinded crystals of compounds 1-5 have been recorded. Similar diffraction patterns for the simulated data (calculated from the single crystal X-ray data) and observed data prove the bulk homogeneity of the samples (see Section 5 of  for the PXRD patterns of the compounds 1-5).

elements.content: The IR spectra of compounds 1−5 have some common features as far as molybdenum−oxygen bonds are concerned because compounds 1−4 contain the same isopolyanion [Mo7O24]6−, and compound 5 includes a similar cluster anion [Mo8O27]6−. A very similar feature in the range of 880−990 cm−1 in the IR spectra of compounds 1−5 is assigned to the characteristic absorption for Mo−Ot (Ot = terminal oxygen). The vibrational bands aroused in the region of 1000−1650 cm−1 can be assigned to the bending vibrations (either C−H or N−H) or aromatic ring stretching frequencies of the aminopyridine moieties. Compound [2-ampH]4[{Zn(H2O)5}Mo7O24]·9H2O (1) shows a considerable amount of red shift for C−N vibration in its IR spectrum when compared to the C−N vibration of free 2-aminopyridine molecule, which appears at 1442 cm−1. This red shift is due to the protonation of ring nitrogen atom in 2-aminopyridine. In compounds 2−5, similar red shifts are observed for C−N vibration. A representative IR spectrum (compound 1) is shown in Figure S9 (, Section 4).
elements.clean_text:
Spectroscopy and Thermal Studies

IR Spectroscopy

The IR spectra of compounds 1-5 have some common features as far as molybdenum-oxygen bonds are concerned because compounds 1-4 contain the same isopolyanion [Mo7O24]6-, and compound 5 includes a similar cluster anion [Mo8O27]6-. A very similar feature in the range of 880-990 cm-1 in the IR spectra of compounds 1-5 is assigned to the characteristic absorption for Mo-Ot (Ot = terminal oxygen). The vibrational bands aroused in the region of 1000-1650 cm-1 can be assigned to the bending vibrations (either C-H or N-H) or aromatic ring stretching frequencies of the aminopyridine moieties. Compound [2-ampH]4[{Zn(H2O)5}Mo7O24]⋅9H2O (1) shows a considerable amount of red shift for C-N vibration in its IR spectrum when compared to the C-N vibration of free 2-aminopyridine molecule, which appears at 1442 cm-1. This red shift is due to the protonation of ring nitrogen atom in 2-aminopyridine. In compounds 2-5, similar red shifts are observed for C-N vibration. A representative IR spectrum (compound 1) is shown in Figure S9 (, Section 4).

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed in the temperature range of 30−1100 °C. The TG curve for compound [2-ampH]4[{Zn(H2O)5}Mo7O24]·9H2O (1) shows the first weight loss of 14.01% in the temperature range of 35−130 °C (Figure ). This weight loss corresponds to the loss of 14 water molecules (calculated mass loss for 14 water molecules is 14.37%). This includes nine noncoordinated and five zinc coordinated water molecules per formula unit. The total weight loss in the temperature range of 150−750 °C of 38% is due to the oxidation of 2-aminopyridine molecules and the structural decomposition of the {ZnMo7O24}4− moiety (Figure ). The water mass loss and carbon dioxide evolution curves have been shown in blue and pink color respectively in the same Figure . Compounds 2 and 3 are isostructural and hence show identical TG/mass curves (Figure , panels a and b, respectively). Each compound contains eight (four lattice and four metal coordinated water molecules) water molecules which are evolved in the temperature range of 35−150 °C with a loss of 9.01% for 2, and 9.18% for 3 (calculated mass loss for eight water molecules is 8.28 for 2, and 8.31 for 3). The total weight loss in the temperature range of 150−750 °C of 42.5% for 2 and 42.17% for 3 is due to the oxidation of 3-aminopyridine molecules and the structural decomposition of {ZnMo7O24}4− and {CoMo7O24}4− moieties, respectively. The corresponding water mass loss and carbondioxide mass loss curves are shown in blue and purple color, respectively (Figure a,b).

The water mass loss and carbon dioxide evolution curves have been shown in blue and pink color respectively in the same Figure . Compounds 2 and 3 are isostructural and hence show identical TG/mass curves (Figure , panels a and b, respectively). Each compound contains eight (four lattice and four metal coordinated water molecules) water molecules which are evolved in the temperature range of 35-150 °C with a loss of 9.01% for 2, and 9.18% for 3 (calculated mass loss for eight water molecules is 8.28 for 2, and 8.31 for 3). The total weight loss in the temperature range of 150-750 °C of 42.5% for 2 and 42.17% for 3 is due to the oxidation of 3-aminopyridine molecules and the structural decomposition of {ZnMo7O24}4- and {CoMo7O24}4- moieties, respectively. elements.content: TG curve for compound [2,3-diampH]4[Co(H2O)6][Mo7O24]·6H2O (4) shows the first weight loss of 12.10% in the temperature range of 35−310 °C (Figure c). This weight loss corresponds to the loss of 12 water molecules (calculated mass loss for 12 water molecules is 12.18%). This includes six noncoordinated and six cobalt coordinated water molecules per formula unit. The second weight loss of 33.10% in the temperature range of 410−650 °C might be due to the oxidation of 2,3-diaminopyridinium moieties and the structural decomposition of the POM cluster moiety associated with cobalt coordination complex. TG curve for compound [2,3-diampH]2[{Zn(2,3-diampH)2(H2O)2}Mo8O27]·2H2O (5) shows the first weight loss of 4.18% in the temperature range of 35−220 °C as shown in Figure d. This weight loss corresponds to the loss of four water molecules (calculated mass loss for four water molecules is 4.05%). This includes two noncoordinated and two zinc coordinated water molecules per formula unit. The total weight loss of 37.2% in the temperature range of 380−500 °C is assigned to structural disintegration of the rest part of the compound, as found for the other four compounds.

elements.content: In the case of cobalt compound [3-ampH]4[{Co(3-ampy)(H2O)4}Mo7O24]·4H2O (3), the solid state electronic absorption spectra were recorded before and after its dehydration. The diffuse reflectance spectrum of compound 3 is shown in Figure a that shows a broad feature (d−d transition) around 450−500 nm due the presence of octahedral Co(II) species. When this solid (pink colored) was heated/dehydrated, the color of the solid became dark brown. The diffuse reflectance spectrum of this heated/dehydrated solid is described in Figure b showing the appearance of a new band at 546 nm. This new feature in the electronic absorption spectrum of the heated/dehydrated solid of compound 3 could be due to the formation of tetrahedral Co(II) species. The formation of Co(III) species also cannot be ruled out.

elements.content: Heptamolydate (also known as paramolybdate) is the most common chemical of molybdenum (as ammonium salt) that we see in any general chemical laboratory. Its crystal structure is also well-established. Ammonium heptamolybdate has been used as an oxidation catalyst in industry. Its catalysis value increases if it supports/it is functionalized by a transition metal coordination complex on its surface. However, instances of paramolybdate supported transition metal complexes (as a discrete entity) are very rare. We have described here a series of paramolydate supported zinc coordination complexes stressing their supramolecular structures. We have described a new type of linked structure that is formed by a corner-shared condensed chain, in which the supported zinc coordination complex plays an important role to result in a 2-D coordination polymer. We have demonstrated that dimer of 2-aminopyridine plays an important role as a supramolecular synthon in the construction of a well-defined three-dimensional supramolecular structure. We have also shown how a POM-supported transition metal coordination complex can act as a tecton.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Heptamolydate (also known as paramolybdate) is the most common chemical of molybdenum (as ammonium salt) that we see in any general chemical laboratory. Its crystal structure is also well-established. Ammonium heptamolybdate has been used as an oxidation catalyst in industry. Its catalysis value increases if it supports/it is functionalized by a transition metal coordination complex on its surface. However, instances of paramolybdate supported transition metal complexes (as a discrete entity) are very rare. We have described here a series of paramolydate supported zinc coordination complexes stressing their supramolecular structures. We have described a new type of linked structure that is formed by a corner-shared condensed chain, in which the supported zinc coordination complex plays an important role to result in a 2-D coordination polymer. We have demonstrated that dimer of 2-aminopyridine plays an important role as a supramolecular synthon in the construction of a well-defined three-dimensional supramolecular structure. We have also shown how a POM-supported transition metal coordination complex can act as a tecton.

cln_elements.content:
Sodium molybdate (1 g, 4.13 mmol in the case of compounds 1−3 and 0.5 g, 2.07 mmol in the case of compounds 4−5) was dissolved in 100 mL of water and its pH was adjusted to 2.0 by conc. HCl. In a separate beaker, the metal salt M(NO3)2·6H2O (M = Zn2+, 0.5 g, 1.68 mmol for compounds 1−2; 0.25 g, 0.86 mmol for compound 5; Co2+, 0.5 g, 1.72 mmol for compound 3 and 0.25 g, 0.86 mmol for compound 4) and aminopyridine derivatives (0.2 g, 2.13 mmol of 2-aminopyridine for compound 1 and 3-aminopyridine for compounds 2−3 and 0.12 g, 1.10 mmol of 2,3-diaminopyridine for compounds 4−5) were dissolved in 20 mL of water. This reaction mixture of aminopyridine derivative and divalent metal salt was added dropwise to the sodium molybdate solution with stirring. The resulting reaction mixture was stirred for 6 h (during stirring, the formation of precipitate/turbidity was dissolved by heating the reaction mixture at 70−80 °C in three to four slots). The reaction mixture was then filtered and kept in an open beaker for crystallization without any disturbance at room temperature. After one week, crystals formed, were filtered, washed with plenty of water, and finally dried at room temperature. One of the single crystals from each, suitable for X-ray diffraction study, was selected and characterized structurally.

A General Synthetic Strategy for Compounds 1-5 

Sodium molybdate (1 g, 4.13 mmol in the case of compounds 1-3 and 0.5 g, 2.07 mmol in the case of compounds 4-5) was dissolved in 100 mL of water and its pH was adjusted to 2.0 by conc. HCl. This reaction mixture of aminopyridine derivative and divalent metal salt was added dropwise to the sodium molybdate solution with stirring. cln_elements.content:
Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed in the temperature range of 30−1100 °C. The TG curve for compound [2-ampH]4[{Zn(H2O)5}Mo7O24]·9H2O (1) shows the first weight loss of 14.01% in the temperature range of 35−130 °C (Figure ). This weight loss corresponds to the loss of 14 water molecules (calculated mass loss for 14 water molecules is 14.37%). This includes nine noncoordinated and five zinc coordinated water molecules per formula unit. The total weight loss in the temperature range of 150−750 °C of 38% is due to the oxidation of 2-aminopyridine molecules and the structural decomposition of the {ZnMo7O24}4− moiety (Figure ). The water mass loss and carbon dioxide evolution curves have been shown in blue and pink color respectively in the same Figure . Compounds 2 and 3 are isostructural and hence show identical TG/mass curves (Figure , panels a and b, respectively). Each compound contains eight (four lattice and four metal coordinated water molecules) water molecules which are evolved in the temperature range of 35−150 °C with a loss of 9.01% for 2, and 9.18% for 3 (calculated mass loss for eight water molecules is 8.28 for 2, and 8.31 for 3). The total weight loss in the temperature range of 150−750 °C of 42.5% for 2 and 42.17% for 3 is due to the oxidation of 3-aminopyridine molecules and the structural decomposition of {ZnMo7O24}4− and {CoMo7O24}4− moieties, respectively. The corresponding water mass loss and carbondioxide mass loss curves are shown in blue and purple color, respectively (Figure a,b).

TG curve for compound [2,3-diampH]4[Co(H2O)6][Mo7O24]·6H2O (4) shows the first weight loss of 12.10% in the temperature range of 35−310 °C (Figure c). This weight loss corresponds to the loss of 12 water molecules (calculated mass loss for 12 water molecules is 12.18%). This includes six noncoordinated and six cobalt coordinated water molecules per formula unit. The second weight loss of 33.10% in the temperature range of 410−650 °C might be due to the oxidation of 2,3-diaminopyridinium moieties and the structural decomposition of the POM cluster moiety associated with cobalt coordination complex. TG curve for compound [2,3-diampH]2[{Zn(2,3-diampH)2(H2O)2}Mo8O27]·2H2O (5) shows the first weight loss of 4.18% in the temperature range of 35−220 °C as shown in Figure d. This weight loss corresponds to the loss of four water molecules (calculated mass loss for four water molecules is 4.05%). This includes two noncoordinated and two zinc coordinated water molecules per formula unit. The total weight loss of 37.2% in the temperature range of 380−500 °C is assigned to structural disintegration of the rest part of the compound, as found for the other four compounds.

Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed in the temperature range of 30-1100 °C. The TG curve for compound [2-ampH]4[{Zn(H2O)5}Mo7O24]⋅9H2O (1) shows the first weight loss of 14.01% in the temperature range of 35-130 °C (Figure ). This weight loss corresponds to the loss of 14 water molecules (calculated mass loss for 14 water molecules is 14.37%). This includes nine noncoordinated and five zinc coordinated water molecules per formula unit. The total weight loss in the temperature range of 150-750 °C of 38% is due to the oxidation of 2-aminopyridine molecules and the structural decomposition of the {ZnMo7O24}4- moiety (Figure ). The water mass loss and carbon dioxide evolution curves have been shown in blue and pink color respectively in the same Figure . Compounds 2 and 3 are isostructural and hence show identical TG/mass curves (Figure , panels a and b, respectively). Each compound contains eight (four lattice and four metal coordinated water molecules) water molecules which are evolved in the temperature range of 35-150 °C with a loss of 9.01% for 2, and 9.18% for 3 (calculated mass loss for eight water molecules is 8.28 for 2, and 8.31 for 3). The total weight loss in the temperature range of 150-750 °C of 42.5% for 2 and 42.17% for 3 is due to the oxidation of 3-aminopyridine molecules and the structural decomposition of {ZnMo7O24}4- and {CoMo7O24}4- moieties, respectively. The corresponding water mass loss and carbondioxide mass loss curves are shown in blue and purple color, respectively (Figure a,b).

TG curve for compound [2,3-diampH]4[Co(H2O)6][Mo7O24]⋅6H2O (4) shows the first weight loss of 12.10% in the temperature range of 35-310 °C (Figure c). This weight loss corresponds to the loss of 12 water molecules (calculated mass loss for 12 water molecules is 12.18%). This includes six noncoordinated and six cobalt coordinated water molecules per formula unit. The second weight loss of 33.10% in the temperature range of 410-650 °C might be due to the oxidation of 2,3-diaminopyridinium moieties and the structural decomposition of the POM cluster moiety associated with cobalt coordination complex. TG curve for compound [2,3-diampH]2[{Zn(2,3-diampH)2(H2O)2}Mo8O27]⋅2H2O (5) shows the first weight loss of 4.18% in the temperature range of 35-220 °C as shown in Figure d. This weight loss corresponds to the loss of four water molecules (calculated mass loss for four water molecules is 4.05%). This includes two noncoordinated and two zinc coordinated water molecules per formula unit. The total weight loss of 37.2% in the temperature range of 380-500 °C is assigned to structural disintegration of the rest part of the compound, as found for the other four compounds.

<fig fig-type="scheme" id="sch2" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label>2</label>
<caption>
<title>Schematic Representation of the Hydrogen Bonded Dimer of 2-Aminopyridine as a Supramolecular Synthon</title>
</caption>
<graphic id="gr2" orientation="portrait" position="anchor" xlink:href="cg-2009-01507z_0008.tif"></graphic>
</fig>
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  Schematic Representation of the Hydrogen Bonded Dimer of 2-Aminopyridine as a Supramolecular Synthon

cln_elements.content: A view showing that the dimer of 2-aminopyridine acts as a synthon; it links the supramolecular water chain (shown in green color) as well as the POM cluster anions (shown in polyhedral representation). Color code: C, dark brown; N, blue; O, green; H, purple.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  A view showing that the dimer of 2-aminopyridine acts as a synthon; it links the supramolecular water chain (shown in green color) as well as the POM cluster anions (shown in polyhedral representation). Color code: C, dark brown; N, blue; O, green; H, purple.

cln_elements.content: (a) The formation of supramolecularly hydrogen bonded water chains, in a view along crystallographic “c” axis in compound 1. (b) Supramolelcular O−H···O hydrogen bonding interactions of a water chain with its surrounding POM supported complex cation in compound 1. Color code: Mo, yellow; Zn, cyan; O, red; oxygen atom from water chain, blue; purple and black dotted lines represent O−H···O hydrogen bonding interactions within water chain and water chain with its surroundings, respectively.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  (a) The formation of supramolecularly hydrogen bonded water chains, in a view along crystallographic "c" axis in compound 1. (b) Supramolelcular O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonding interactions of a water chain with its surrounding POM supported complex cation in compound 1. Color code: Mo, yellow; Zn, cyan; O, red; oxygen atom from water chain, blue; purple and black dotted lines represent O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonding interactions within water chain and water chain with its surroundings, respectively.

cln_elements.content: A three-dimensional supramolecular network having well-defined channels that accommodate the dimer of 2-aminopyridine (synthon).
cln_elements.clean_text: 4  A three-dimensional supramolecular network having well-defined channels that accommodate the dimer of 2-aminopyridine (synthon).

cln_elements.content: The thermal ellipsoidal plot (50% probability) of the molecular structure of compound [3-ampH]4[{Zn(3-ampy)(H2O)4}Mo7O24]·4H2O (2) excluding lattice water molecules.
cln_elements.clean_text: 5  The thermal ellipsoidal plot (50% probability) of the molecular structure of compound [3-ampH]4[{Zn(3-ampy)(H2O)4}Mo7O24]⋅4H2O (2) excluding lattice water molecules.

cln_elements.content: (a) The three-dimensional supramolecular network formed by O−H···O hydrogen bonding interactions having well-defined irregular rectangular grid channels in compound 2. (b) View for guest 3-aminopyridine molecules which are situated in irregular rectangular grid channels. Color code: C, dark brown; N, green; polyhedral representation of polyoxometalate cluster anions and zinc-aqua complexes are shown in light brown and cyan color, respectively; oxygen atom from water pentamer and a lattice water molecule are involved in O−H···O hydrogen bonding interactions, purple; purple and blue dotted lines represent the O−H···O hydrogen bonding interactions of polyoxometalate cluster anions with water pentamer and a lattice water molecule, respectively.
cln_elements.clean_text: 6  (a) The three-dimensional supramolecular network formed by O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonding interactions having well-defined irregular rectangular grid channels in compound 2. (b) View for guest 3-aminopyridine molecules which are situated in irregular rectangular grid channels. Color code: C, dark brown; N, green; polyhedral representation of polyoxometalate cluster anions and zinc-aqua complexes are shown in light brown and cyan color, respectively; oxygen atom from water pentamer and a lattice water molecule are involved in O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonding interactions, purple; purple and blue dotted lines represent the O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonding interactions of polyoxometalate cluster anions with water pentamer and a lattice water molecule, respectively.

cln_elements.content: The thermal ellipsoidal plot (50% probability) of the molecular structure of compound [2,3-diampH]4[Co(H2O)6][Mo7O24]·6H2O (4) excluding cobalt-aqua complex cation and lattice water molecules.
cln_elements.clean_text: 7  The thermal ellipsoidal plot (50% probability) of the molecular structure of compound [2,3-diampH]4[Co(H2O)6][Mo7O24]⋅6H2O (4) excluding cobalt-aqua complex cation and lattice water molecules.

cln_elements.content: (a) The thermal ellipsoidal plot (50% probability) of compound 5 excluding hydrogen atoms and solvent water molecules. (b) The molecular structure of [2,3-diampH]2[{Zn(2,3-diampH)2(H2O)2}Mo8O27]·2H2O in compound 5 excluding lattice water molecule. Color code: Mo, yellow; Zn, cyan; O, red; C, brown; N, green; H, purple.
cln_elements.clean_text: 8  (a) The thermal ellipsoidal plot (50% probability) of compound 5 excluding hydrogen atoms and solvent water molecules. (b) The molecular structure of [2,3-diampH]2[{Zn(2,3-diampH)2(H2O)2}Mo8O27]⋅2H2O in compound 5 excluding lattice water molecule. Color code: Mo, yellow; Zn, cyan; O, red; C, brown; N, green; H, purple.

cln_elements.content: A view of a one dimentional chain formed by Mo−O−Mo linkage along the crystallographic “c” axis in compound 5 in which each cluster anion is functionalized by zinc coordination complexes [{Zn(2,3-diampH)2(H2O)2}]4+. Color code: Mo, yellow; Zn, cyan; O, red; C, brown; N, green.
cln_elements.clean_text: 9  A view of a one dimentional chain formed by Mo-O-Mo linkage along the crystallographic "c" axis in compound 5 in which each cluster anion is functionalized by zinc coordination complexes [{Zn(2,3-diampH)2(H2O)2}]4+. Color code: Mo, yellow; Zn, cyan; O, red; C, brown; N, green.

cln_elements.content: (a) The lateral linkage of [{Zn(2,3-diampH)2(H2O)2}]4+ with a polyoxometalate cluster anion leads to a two-dimentional layered framework in which well-defined honeycomb cavities also can be seen in compound 5. (b) A view of the accommodation of noncoordinated 2,3-diaminopyridine molecules as guests in the honeycomb cavities. Color code: Zn, cyan; O, red; C from coordinated ligands, dark brown; N from coordinated ligands, green; C from noncoordinated guest ligands, gray; N from noncoordinated guest ligands, purple; polyhedral representation of polyoxometalate cluster anions are shown in light brown.
cln_elements.clean_text: 10  (a) The lateral linkage of [{Zn(2,3-diampH)2(H2O)2}]4+ with a polyoxometalate cluster anion leads to a two-dimentional layered framework in which well-defined honeycomb cavities also can be seen in compound 5. (b) A view of the accommodation of noncoordinated 2,3-diaminopyridine molecules as guests in the honeycomb cavities. Color code: Zn, cyan; O, red; C from coordinated ligands, dark brown; N from coordinated ligands, green; C from noncoordinated guest ligands, gray; N from noncoordinated guest ligands, purple; polyhedral representation of polyoxometalate cluster anions are shown in light brown.
